Steam reforming of tar represents a cost-effective approach for tar removal in biomass gasification. Here, we developed a Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst and unveil the effect of Fe for steam reforming of toluene (SRT) which is a representative tar model compound. The catalyst demonstrated exceptional stability (above 80 % toluene conversion, 3000 mmol/gcat/h H2 yield) over 50 h. The outstanding performance is attributed to the effect of Fe in forming Ni-Fe alloy with the highest reducibility, dispersion, Ni0 ratio, and increased sintering resistance, alongside enhanced electron transfer between Ni and Fe. Fe also promotes H2O adsorption, providing active oxygen for toluene conversion and carbon elimination. Finally, reaction mechanism was explored based on the in-situ DRIFTS and DFT calculations. DFT calculations revealed that Fe sites exhibit higher density of states, electrostatic potential, and d-band center than Ni sites, facilitating H2O coordination. Fe doping reduces energy barriers for H2O splitting and methyl dehydrogenation, while Ni promotes H2 desorption. The synergistic Ni-Fe interaction enables distinct activation of toluene and H2O, respectively. Comparative studies showed Ni/CeO2/CNT suffers from carbon deposition, while Fe/CeO2/CNT exhibits limited activity due to poor reducibility and low Fe0 content. These findings provide critical insights for designing stable Fe-based catalysts for efficient tar removal. Graphical Abstract Keywords Fe doping Water splitting Steam reforming of toluene Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The overexploitation of traditional energy sources has led to severe energy, climate, and environmental crises, driving researchers to actively explore alternative renewable energy solutions [1]. Biomass, characterized by its widespread availability, recyclability, and “zero carbon emission” properties, has emerged as an ideal candidate for sustainable energy production [2]. Among the various technologies employed for biomass conversion—thermochemical, biochemical, and physical methods, the thermochemical processes are particularly notable for their high conversion efficiency and broad applicability [3]. Biomass gasification, a prominent thermochemical technology, is widely regarded as one of the most promising approaches, as it directly converts biomass into syngas, which can be utilized for combustion or as a feedstock for chemical synthesis [4,5]. However, a significant challenge in gasification is the production of tar as a byproduct. This tar tends to condense and accumulate within the gasification system, leading to pipeline blockages, equipment corrosion, and reduced gasification efficiency, thereby hindering the advancement of biomass gasification technology [6]. Catalytic steam reforming has gained considerable attention as an effective method for tar removal, as it converts tar into H2-rich syngas at relatively low reaction temperatures [7]. Given the complex composition of tar, benzene and toluene are frequently employed as model compounds in studies investigating reaction mechanisms and catalyst design [8,9]. While noble metal catalysts exhibit exceptional performance in steam reforming of tar, their high cost limits their widespread application [10,11]. In contrast, transition-metal catalysts such as Ni and Fe offer a cost-effective alternative with performance comparable to noble metals, making them the most widely used catalytic materials in steam reforming of tar [12,13]. For instance, Fe-based catalysts have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in electrochemical water splitting, showing promising applicability in steam reforming reactions [14,15]. Additionally, incorporating Fe into Ni-based catalysts has been shown to enhance the catalytic performance during steam reforming of tar [16,17]. Further, the excellent redox properties of Fe contribute to the reduction of coke formation and prevent the oxidation of Ni in Ni-Fe bimetallic catalysts [18]. The choice of support material is a critical factor influencing the stability of Ni-based catalysts [19]. For instance, Ni/Al2O3 often experience rapid deactivation during tar reforming due to excessive coke formation on the γ-Al2O3 support [20]. CeO2, another commonly used support, has been shown to enhance catalytic activity and anti-coking properties through the formation of Ni-CeO2 nanocomposites, which arise from the strong interaction between Ni and CeO2 [21,22]. Additionally, the abundant oxygen vacancies on the CeO2 surface facilitate oxygen activation and migration during redox reactions [23,24]. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs), one-dimensional tubular structures composed of rolled graphene layers, are frequently employed as catalyst support for steam reforming reactions [25–28]. Because of the high specific surface area, loading active metals onto the inner and outer surfaces of CNTs can significantly increase the number of active sites on the catalyst [25]. The curved structure of CNTs disrupts the electronic balance on their surface, while their excellent electrical conductivity promotes efficient electron transfer during reactions [29]. Moreover, CNTs exhibit exceptional thermal conductivity, enabling uniform and rapid heat distribution during high-temperature reactions, which mitigates localized overheating and inhibits the sintering of active metals [30]. Investigating the reaction mechanism of SRT is of paramount importance for catalyst design and optimization of reaction conditions. In mechanistic studies of SRT, the reaction pathway can be systematically categorized into two fundamental processes: (1) the decomposition of toluene and (2) the dissociation of water [31]. Regarding toluene decomposition, two predominant reaction pathways have been proposed. The first pathway suggests that toluene adsorbed on active sites initially dissociates into adsorbed benzene and methyl species. The adsorbed benzene subsequently undergoes further cleavage into C2 species, which, along with methyl groups, are oxidized by active oxygen species to form aldehyde intermediates. These intermediates then decompose into CO and H*, or undergo complete oxidation to yield CO2 [7,31]. Additionally, a minor fraction of methyl groups may directly react with H* to form CH4 [10]. The alternative pathway involves the initial dehydrogenation of the methyl group in toluene to form C6H5CH2*, which is then progressively oxidized by active oxygen species, generating intermediates such as benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, and benzoate species. The benzoate ultimately undergoes ring-opening and further oxidation to form various gaseous products [32–37]. Concerning water dissociation, the widely accepted mechanism involves the cleavage of water molecules into H* and OH* species [7,10,31]. The H* species combine to form H2, while OH* species, or O* species derived from further dissociation, replenish the consumed active oxygen species [10]. It is noteworthy that although Ni-Fe bimetallic catalysts have been explored for steam reforming of toluene (SRT), the promotional effects of Fe such as enhancing reducibility, boosting water adsorption and splitting, as well as altering electronic structure demand in-depth investigation. Therefore, in this study, by comparative investigation the property and catalytic SRT performance of monometallic Ni/CeO2/CNT and Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst as well as the bimetallic Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst, the role of Fe and the SRT reaction mechanism were unveiled. Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT achieves a stable toluene conversion above 80 % with a high H2 yield of 3000 mmol/gcat/h within 50 h. Its good performance is ascribed to the effect of Fe which formed Ni-Fe alloy with Ni, obtaining the highest Ni0 ratio, metal dispersion, and sintering resistance. Additionally, the electron transfer between Ni and Fe was also enhanced, improving the H2O adsorption capacity, thereby high toluene conversion and low carbon deposition. The reaction mechanism was explored based on the in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments and DFT calculations. It was found that Fe sites decrease the energy barrier for H2O splitting and lowers down the heat absorption for the rate determining step of the methyl dehydrogenation. The synergistic effect between Ni and Fe sites in toluene cracking and H2O splitting, respectively, contributes to the good SRT performance of Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst. By contrast, Ni/CeO2/CNT shows a continuous degradation of toluene conversion as the result of its severe carbon deposition resulted from its largest Ni size. As for Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst, it exhibits the lowest reducibility and least ratio of Fe0, leading to its lowest toluene conversion. The findings from this study offer valuable insights in the development of efficient catalysts for steam reforming of tar. 2 The experimental part 2.1 Material preparation 2.1.1 Purification and functionalization of CNTs The raw CNTs (Suzhou Sinero Technology Co., LTD., diameter: 5–100 nm) and concentrated nitric acid (65 %-68 %) were mixed evenly in proportion (1 g:50 mL) and refluxed at 393 K for 3 h. After the solution was cooled to ambient temperature, CNTs were separated from the mixed solution by high-speed centrifugation and dried at 100 °C overnight to complete the purification. Purified CNTs were added into the mixed solution of hydrogen peroxide (GR, 30 %) and concentrated sulfuric acid (95 %-98 %) by ultrasonic stirring for 3 h, and then filtered, separated and washed with deionized water several times. Finally, the functionalized CNTs were obtained by drying and grinding. 2.1.2 Preparation of catalyst Ni-Fe/CNT was prepared by the wet impregnation method (theoretical loading of both Ni and Fe was 5 wt%). Specifically, a certain amount of CNTs, Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O (98 %, Aladdin) and Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O (98.5 %, Macklin) were added to a small amount of deionized water, which underwent continuously stirring at room temperature for 4 h. After drying at 110 °C, the solid product was crushed to obtain fresh catalyst. The CeO2 was loaded on the surface of CNTs by the chemical deposition method (theoretical loading of CeO2 was 15 wt%). Ni-Fe/CNT was mixed with a certain amount of ethanol, where Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O (99.95 %, Macklin) and C6H12N4 (99.0 %, Aladdin) were added and stirred continuously at 70 °C for 4 h. The separated solids were alternately washed with deionized water and ethanol several times, and then dried overnight at 100 °C. The ground samples were loaded into a tube furnace and calcined in argon atmosphere at 700 °C for 4 h. The calcined catalyst was named Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT. In addition, for comparison, Ni/CeO2/CNT and Fe/CeO2/CNT (both with 10 wt% active metal loading) were prepared by the same method. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts N2 physisorption was performed on samples using Micromeritics ASAP 2460 equipment at 77 K. Prior to analysis, samples underwent degassing at 573 K under vacuum for 4 h to remove physisorbed species. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) theory was applied to determine specific surface areas; the pore size distribution was calculated from the desorption branch data employing the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The TG curve was obtained by the NETZSCH STA449 device with a heating rate of 10 K/min from 373 to 1173 K under air flow. The Raman spectra of the samples were recorded using a LabRAM HR Evolution with a 532 nm laser excitation source. Crystalline structures were examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance, 40 kV and 40 mA) using Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5418 Å) with 2θ ranging from 10° to 80° at a scanning rate of 5°/min. The actual content of Ni and Fe were determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Agilent 5110). Before the test, samples were pretreated by heating at 600 °C for 4 h to burn out the carbon nanotubes, and then dissolved using aqua regia. Morphological features and elemental distribution were investigated using a field-emission transmission electron microscopy (TEM, TECNAI F20) equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) and high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) detectors. Surface chemical environment analysis was conducted using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.7 eV), and the spectral calibration references the binding energy of adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV. Temperature-programmed H2 reduction (H2-TPR), temperature-programmed water desorption (H2O-TPD), and H2 pulse chemisorption were all tested by Micromeritics AutoChem 2950HP coupled with quadrupole mass spectrometry (MKS Cirrus2). For reduction profile analysis, approximately 50 mg samples were initially dehydrated at 573 K, followed by temperature-programmed reduction in 10 % H2/Ar mixture with a heating rate of 10 K/min up to 1123 K, monitoring hydrogen consumption via thermal conductivity detection. In the H2O-TPD, approximately 50 mg of catalyst was initially subjected to in situ reduction under flowing hydrogen (50 mL/min) at 750 °C for 1 h. Following reduction, the system was cooled to 50 °C under inert atmosphere. Water vapor was introduced into the reactor through nitrogen bubbling (50 mL/min) for 1 h to establish adsorption equilibrium. Subsequently, the system was purged with nitrogen at identical flow rate to eliminate physisorbed water species. The temperature was then ramped from 50 to 700 °C at a constant heating rate of 10 °C/min, while monitoring the mass spectrometer signal corresponding to water (m/z = 18) to quantify desorbed species. The H2O-temperature-programmed surface reaction (H2O-TPSR) test was conducted in a Microtrac BelCat II equipped with a mass spectrometer (BelMass). Approximately 50 mg of the catalyst was loaded into a quartz tube. Prior to the test, the catalyst was reduced in situ under a H2 atmosphere at 750 °C for 1 h. After reduction, the catalyst surface was purged with N2 for 0.5 h before cooling commenced. Upon reaching 50 °C, saturated water vapor, generated by bubbling N2 (50 mL/min), was continuously introduced into the quartz tube to initiate the experiment. During the test, the temperature was raised from 50 °C to 700 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min, while H2 evolution (m/z = 2) was monitored by the mass spectrometer. In-situ DRIFTS spectroscopy was carried out on a BRUKER INVENIO-S equipped with an MCT detector and the test samples were mounted in a high-temperature in-situ cell (Harrick). The temperature of the cell was raised to 650 °C before starting the test, then the samples were reduced by H2 for 1 h. N2 was introduced at the end of the reduction, and the background was recorded separately when it was lowered to the test temperature. Then water and toluene were brought into the in-situ cell by bubbling with N2, and after saturation adsorption of the samples, the profiles at different reaction temperatures were recorded. Each profile was scanned 64 times with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and all profiles were subtracted from the background. 2.3 Reforming experiment The SRT was performed in a fixed-bed reactor equipped with a titanium tube (inner diameter 8.0 mm), three mass flow controllers (MFC), a two-channel injection pump and an online gas chromatograph. First, 50 mg of catalyst was loaded into the tube. Then 20 mL/min of N2 was injected after the reactor temperature was raised from room temperature to 750 °C at the rate of 10 °C/min. Subsequently, 20 mL/min of H2 was injected for in-situ reduction for 1 h. After the reduction, the temperature of the reactor was reduced to 700 °C, toluene (0.025 mL/min) and water (S/C=1–3) were vaporized into gas by a high temperature preheater at 300 °C, and then were introduced into the tube together with N2. The total gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 6000 h−1. A cold trap was set up at the outlet to separate the liquid mixture that was not completely converted from the gas products. The Shimadzu GC-2014 gas chromatograph equipped with TCD and FID detectors was used for analysis of the gas products. The toluene conversion was calculated as follows: (1) X = n CO , out + n CO 2 , out + n CH 4 , out 7 n C 7 H 8 , in × 100 % where, n CO , out , n CO 2 , out , n CH 4 , out , and n C 7 H 8 , in represent the molar flow rates of CO, CO2, and CH4, and the molar flow rates of toluene passing into the reactor, respectively. To ensure data reliability, carbon balance was carefully monitored during toluene conversion analysis, and only results with a carbon balance > 90 % were deemed acceptable. To assess the catalytic performance, the reaction rate was expressed in terms of turnover frequency (TOF), which was derived from the toluene conversion according to the Eq. (2): (2) TOF ( h − 1 ) = n C 7 H 8 , in × X × M m catalyst × D × L L, D, and M are the loading, dispersion, and molar mass of Ni in the catalyst, respectively, m catalyst is the catalyst mass (g). 2.4 Theoretical calculation The structural configurations and electronic characteristics were comprehensively examined through first-principles calculations based on Density Functional Theory (DFT), as implemented in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). Exchange-correlation effects were treated using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional, with the inclusion of the DFT-D3-BJ empirical correction to properly account for dispersion interactions [38,39]. In our slab model calculations, structural relaxations were performed by allowing two outermost atomic layers to fully optimize their positions. The electronic wavefunctions were expanded in a plane-wave basis set with an energy cutoff of 400 eV to ensure convergence of the calculated properties. For Brillouin zone sampling, we employed a Monkhorst-Pack grid with dimensions of 3 × 2 × 1 in reciprocal space. The self-consistent field calculations were considered converged when the total energy difference between successive iterations fell below 1 × 10−5 eV, and the maximum residual force on any atom was less than 0.02 eV Å−1. To identify transition states along reaction pathways, we utilized both the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) approach and the DIMER algorithm. All post-processing analyses and data extraction were performed using the VASPKIT toolkit, which enabled efficient handling of the computational outputs [40]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material characterization Fig. 1A and B show the XRD patterns of the three catalysts after calcination and reduction. The diffraction peaks of CNTs and CeO2 (JCPDS No.75–0390) can be seen in Fig. 1A, indicating that CeO2 was successfully deposited on CNTs. In addition, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni0 were observed for Ni/CeO2/CNT even without reduction treatment, which was consistent with the observation reported in other articles [28,41,42]. This can be attributed to the fact that some of the CNTs pyrolyzed to reduce the NiO loaded on their surfaces during the high temperature calcination process. Similarly, only the characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 were observed for Fe/CeO2/CNT, which suggests that Fe oxides are more difficult to be reduced to Fe0 by CNTs compared with NiO during heat treatment. For Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT, both Ni0 and Fe3O4 present, which is in line with the patterns observed from the other two monometallic catalysts. After reduction treatment by H2 (Fig. 1B), part of Fe3O4 in Fe/CeO2/CNT was reduced to metal Fe0, which further suggests that Fe3O4 is difficult to be completely reduced [43]. In addition, the diffraction peaks of Ni-Fe alloy (JCPDS No. 88–2324) were observed for Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT, indicating that the reduction with H2 is a necessary pretreatment for the formation of Ni-Fe alloy. The crystallite size of Ni-Fe alloy (12.0 nm, Table 1) calculated via Scherrer's formula is the smallest, indicating that Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT may have the highest catalytic activity. By comparison, although the crystallite size of Fe (12.8 nm) is smaller than that of Ni (18.2 nm), the content of metal species in Fe/CeO2/CNT was much smaller than that in Ni/CeO2/CNT as shall be discussed later, which may lead to the worse catalytic performance of the former catalyst. Fig. 1C depicts the adsorption and desorption curves of all catalysts, which belong to Type IV isotherms with H1 hysteresis loops according to the classification rules of IUPAC [44–46]. Fig. 1D shows that the diameters of the pores on the surface of the three catalysts are mainly distributed in the range of 2–4 nm. These results suggest that the catalysts are all mesoporous materials and coincide with the structural features of CNTs [27]. It is also worth noting that a certain number of pores are also distributed in the range of 5–70 nm, which may be due to the uneven distribution of the inner diameters of CNTs. Fe/CeO2/CNT displayed the smallest specific surface area (171.1 m2/g, Table 1). This can be ascribed to the blockage of some small pores on the surface of CNTs by Fe3O4 species [47], which also can be verified from its smallest pore volume and largest average pore size. As for Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT, it has the smallest average pore size. This can be due to the even distribution of Ni and Fe ( Fig. 2E) as well as their partial occupation of the CNTs channels. The morphologies of the three catalysts were characterized by TEM as shown in Fig. 2. Because of the excellent thermal stability, most of the CNTs can still maintain a clear and intact tubular structure after the catalyst has been reduced at a high temperature (Fig. 2A-C). Additionally, it can be seen that a large number of metal or Fe3O4 particles are loaded on the surface of the CNTs. Some large Fe3O4 particles on Fe/CeO2/CNT are more likely to block the pores on the surface of CNTs (Fig. 2B), resulting in its smallest specific surface. This is also consistent with its results of N2 physisorption analysis (Fig. 1C and Table 1). The Ni (111), Fe (110), and (Fe, Ni) alloy crystal planes with the crystal plane spacing of 0.203 nm, 0.202 nm, and 0.208 nm, respectively were also observed for Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT (Fig. 2D) [7,48,49]. It can be found that the aggregation of metal particles is mitigated with a more uniform distribution on CNTs due to the addition of a second metal (Fig. 2E). In order to investigate the reducibility of the three catalysts, H2-TPR profiles were recorded from 50 °C to 700 °C. As shown in Fig. 3A, by fitting the H2-TPR profiles, the reduction profiles of each sample could be fitted to four reduction peaks, and then the areas of the reduction peaks were integrated to compare the reduction properties of different compositions, as shown in Table 2. Peak I and peak II can be due to the reduction of lattice oxygen of CeO2 on its surface [50,51]. Peak III and peak IV mainly represent the reduction of Ni or Fe species with weak and strong interaction with support, respectively [52]. It can be observed that Fe/CeO2/CNT has the lowest reducibility with most of its reduction peaks (over 60 % for peak III and peak IV) located above 485 °C, indicating that Fe species in Fe/CeO2/CNT is the most difficult to be reduced, which is in accordance with the XRD results and which may result in its low SRT activity as shall be discussed later. By comparison, Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT has the highest reducibility with more than 84 % of its reduction peaks (peak I, II, and III) presented below 403 °C. This can be attributed to the weakening of the interactions between Fe and the support due to the synergistic effect produced by the formation of Ni-Fe alloy [53]. This may contribute to the highest amount of Ni0 and Fe0 on the surface of Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT as confirmed from the XPS results later. Additionally, the formation of Ni-Fe alloy also enhanced the sintering resistance of Ni metal, boosting its SRT catalytic performance. In addition, the reduction temperatures of CeO2 in Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT and Ni/CeO2/CNT are also lower compared with those in Fe/CeO2/CNT. This can be due to the formation of Ni-O-Ce between Ni and CeO2, promoting the reduction of CeO2 [51]. It is interesting that the reducibility of Ni/CeO2/CNT (48.4 % for peak III and peak IV) was higher than that of Fe/CeO2/CNT, producing more Ni0 species as confirmed from XRD in Fig. 1B and the XPS results later thereby leading to its better SRT activity than that of Fe/CeO2/CNT. However, compared with Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT, Ni/CeO2/CNT exhibited a worse stability probably because of its worse carbon deposition resistance of Ni compared with the Ni-Fe alloy. The water adsorption capacity of the three catalysts was determined by H2O-TPD as shown in Fig. 3B. In order to make a more intuitive comparison, the Gaussian function was used to fit the profiles. The H2O-TPD profiles of all catalysts could be fitted into four peaks: below 130 °C (physically adsorbed type I water), 130–200 °C (type II water interacting with species such as hydroxide via hydrogen bonding), 200–350 °C (type III water combing with the catalyst to form H-OH active sites), and above 350 °C (type IV water due to the desorption of hydroxides) [35,54]. Among these four types of water, type III water can further split to provide active protons, promoting the oxidation of toluene and inhibiting the formation of carbon during SRT [54,55]. Further analysis reveals that the proportion of type III water exhibits no significant difference between the monometallic catalysts of Ni/CeO2/CNT and Fe/CeO2/CNT. However, upon the incorporation of Fe to form Ni-Fe alloy, a remarkable enhancement in the proportion of type III water is observed ( Table 3). This phenomenon suggests that the synergistic interaction between Ni and Fe facilitates the adsorption of water, particularly the type III water, on the catalyst surface. These adsorbed water molecules may subsequently undergo dissociation during the SRT reaction, thereby providing additional active oxygen species and good SRT performance. The water dissociation capabilities of the three catalysts were compared via H2O-TPSR, with the results presented in Fig. 3C. Fitting the H₂ mass spectrometry profiles using Gaussian functions enabled determination of the water dissociation temperature on each catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. 3C, only a small quantity of water dissociated at elevated temperatures (524 °C) over Ni/CeO2/CNT, indicating weak water dissociation activity at the Ni sites. This may subsequently hinder the generation of sufficient active oxygen species during the reaction to eliminate carbon deposits from the catalyst surface, leading to rapid catalyst deactivation. In contrast, the Fe/CeO2/CNT facilitated water dissociation at significantly lower temperatures (374 °C), demonstrating superior catalytic activity for water dissociation at Fe sites compared to Ni sites. Furthermore, upon formation of the Ni-Fe alloy (Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT), the onset temperature for water dissociation decreased further to 311 °C. Concurrently, the peak centered at 583 °C indicates that Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT generates substantially more H2 within a temperature range closer to actual reaction conditions. These findings collectively demonstrate that Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT exhibits the strongest water dissociation capability among the three catalysts. They also confirm that Fe effectively enhances the catalyst efficiency for water dissociation, enabling it to function as a dual active site alongside Ni in SRT. Notably, although Fe/CeO2/CNT facilitates considerable water dissociation at relatively low temperatures, its weaker adsorption capacity for type III water resulted in inferior catalytic performance compared to Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT. In order to characterize the chemical states of different elements on the catalyst surfaces after reduction, XPS was performed as depicted in Fig. 3D-F. The XPS spectra of Ni 2p3/2 are shown in Fig. 3D, where the binding energies of 853.0 eV, 854.2 eV, and 855.0–859.0 eV are assigned to Ni0, Ni2+, and satellite peaks, respectively [26]. The binding energies of Fe0, Fe2+, and Fe3O4 in the Fe 2p3/2 XPS spectra (Fig. 3E) are located at 707.0 eV, 710.2 eV, and 711.5 eV, respectively [56]. It was observable that after doping Fe, the binding energies of Ni0 in Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT moved to lower values compared with that in Ni/CeO2/CNT (Fig. 3D). Whereas, the binding energies of Fe species in Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT moved to higher values compared with those in Fe/CeO2/CNT (Fig. 3E). These results indicated that the formation of Ni-Fe alloy promotes the migration of electrons from Fe to Ni. This also resulted in the slightly higher Ni0/Ni2+ ratio in Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT compared with that in Ni/CeO2/CNT ( Table 4). In addition, it was noted that the Fe0 content in the two Fe containing catalysts is very low, which confirms that Fe in these catalysts mainly exists in the form of oxidation state. This is consistent with the XRD (Fig. 1B) and H2-TPR results (Fig. 3A). The Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 3F) were deconvoluted into eight peaks v, v’, v’’, v’’’, u, u’, u’’, and u’’’, where v’ and u’ stand for Ce3+ and v, v’’, v’’’, u, u’’, as well as u’’’ represent Ce4+, respectively [57]. It was found that the concentration of oxygen vacancy (Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+)) in different catalysts (Table 4) was approximately equal, making equal contributions to their catalytic performance. 3.2 SRT catalytic performance of M/CeO2/CNT 3.2.1 Effect of reaction temperature The influence of reaction temperature on catalytic performance in SRT, maintaining constant operational parameters with a S/C molar ratio of 2 and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 6000 h−1 as demonstrated in Fig. 4. As can be seen from Fig. 4A, the toluene conversion of the three catalysts increased with the increase of the reaction temperature from 600 °C to 700 °C due to the endothermic nature of SRT reaction [49]. However, when the reaction temperature is further increased to 750 °C, the catalytic activity of Ni/CeO2/CNT and Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT begin to decline, indicating that high temperature may also lead to sintering of the active components on these two catalysts to reduce their catalytic activities, which can be verified from the increased crystalline size from the XRD characterizations after reaction as shall be discussed later. Among the three catalysts, Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT showed a comparable toluene conversion of 88.0 % at 700 °C with that of Ni/CeO2/CNT (90.8 %, Fig. 4A). By contrast, Fe/CeO2/CNT showed little catalytic activity for SRT. The composition of products was also analyzed as shown in Fig. 4B and Fig. S1 in Supplementary material. As can be found from Fig. 4B, the H2 yield on Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT peaked at 700 °C (3350 mmol/gcat/h). Whereas, when the temperature continued to rise to 750 °C, the H2 yield began to decline, mainly because the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction occurred to consume H2 and CO2 to produce CO. Interestingly, although Ni/CeO2/CNT has the best catalytic activity over the entire temperature range (Fig. 4A), its H2 yield is significantly lower than that of Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT at 700 °C (Fig. S1). This suggests that although the incorporation of Fe slightly reduced the catalyst activity of Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT, the H2 yield was greatly improved due to the enhanced water adsorption and dissociation as discussed from the H2O-TPD and H2O-TPSR data (Fig. 3B and C) and thereby the efficiency of water splitting to produce H2. However, it is worth noting that the H2 yield on Fe/CeO2/CNT is still very low, indicating that the efficiency for water splitting is dependent on the conversion of toluene. 3.2.2 Effect of the molar ratio of steam to carbon in feedstock The effect of the molar ratio of steam to carbon (S/C) on toluene conversion and product composition was also examined at 700 °C as shown in Fig. 4C and D. When the S/C ratio equals to 1, the toluene conversion gradually decreased for Ni/CeO2/CNT (from 90.7 % to 30.7 %) and Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT (from 63.3 % to 19.1 %) during the 10 h time of stream (TOS). The main reason lead to their decrease can be attributed to that little H2O could not provide enough active oxygen for the SRT reaction [7]. With the proceed of SRT reaction, the carbon deposition gradually increased to cover the active sites on the catalyst. When the S/C ratio increased to 2, the toluene conversion on Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT increased significantly and showed excellent catalytic stability. This is because Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT has the highest water adsorption (Fig. 3B) and splitting ability to provide active oxygen to promote the SRT and carbon elimination. Due to the increase of toluene conversion and the decrease of carbon deposition, the yield of syngas is also significantly improved (Fig. 4D). By contrast, for Ni/CeO2/CNT, the increase of S/C ratio did not obviously increase its initial toluene conversion compared with that of Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT. This can be ascribed to the smaller adsorption capacity for water of Ni/CeO2/CNT. Whereas, more water provides more amount of active oxygen to accelerate the elimination of carbon, slowing down the decline of its activity. Further increase the S/C ratio to 3 resulted in the decrease in toluene conversion (from 88.6 % to 81.8 %), the H2 yield, as well as the stability for Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT. This suggests that the catalyst has been saturated with excess H2O, reducing the adsorption sites of toluene therefore decreasing the toluene conversion [58]. Notably, the Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst showed the lowest toluene conversions under the tested three S/C ratios, further suggesting that it is hardly active for SRT probably due to its low reducibility to Fe0 species as confirmed from XRD (Fig. 1B), H2-TPR (Fig. 3A), and XPS results (Fig. 3E). To further confirm the promoting effect of Fe content, we verified the Ni/Fe ratio while maintained the total active metal loading of 10 wt% and prepared the 3Ni-7Fe/CeO2/CNT and 7Ni-3Fe/CeO2/CNT catalysts for SRT. As can be seen from Fig. S5, under the optimal reaction conditions (T = 700 °C, S/C=2), the toluene conversion during SRT over the 7Ni-3Fe/CeO2/CNT declined from 89.9 % to 70.2 % within 10 h. This indicates that while this catalyst exhibits superior initial catalytic activity towards toluene, its stability is significantly inferior to that of the Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT. Conversely, the 3Ni-7Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst demonstrated reasonable stability but achieved a maximum toluene conversion of only 78.5 %, substantially lower than Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT. This suggests that the catalytic activity for toluene is predominantly governed by the Ni content. Further analysis of the gas composition revealed that the H2 yield for both 3Ni-7Fe/CeO2/CNT and 7Ni-3Fe/CeO2/CNT remained below 3000 mmol/gcat/h. This demonstrates that the Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT also possesses the highest water dissociation activity among the three catalysts tested. Collectively, these results confirm the superior overall catalytic performance of Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT for SRT. 3.2.3 Structure and SRT performance relationship The TOF and apparent activation energy (Ea) values of Ni/CeO2/CNT and Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT (Fig. 4E) were also calculated based on the metal dispersion data (Table 1) and intrinsic toluene conversion data which were controlled below 20 % after exclusion of mass transfer limitations [31,49]. From the dispersion data (Table 1), it was found that Fe/CeO2/CNT had an extremely low dispersion of 0.2 %, which may be attributed to its low reducibility and poor H2 adsorption [16,18]. By comparison, the metal dispersions for Ni/CeO2/CNT and Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT were 9.4 % and 10.6 %, respectively, indicating that Fe promotes the uniform dispersion of Ni and enhances the reducibility of Ni/CeO2/CNT as discussed in the H2-TPR result (Fig. 3A). Additionally, Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT exhibited a lower Ea of 75.6 kJ/mol (Fig. 4E) and higher TOF value of 186.8 h−1 (Table 1), respectively, indicating its highest SRT activity among the three catalysts under investigation. In order to further explore the stability of Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT in SRT, the catalyst was continuously reacted for 50 h TOS as shown in Fig. 4F and Fig. S2. To eliminate potential interference from the support material, a blank control experiment was performed using CeO2/CNT under identical reaction conditions (Fig. S6). The results demonstrate that CeO2/CNT exhibits negligible catalytic activity for SRT. Only trace amounts of toluene underwent thermal cracking at elevated temperatures. Having excluded any significant contribution from the CeO2/CNT support, it can be seen that the toluene conversion was maintained above 80 % with a stable H2 yield of 3000 mmol/gcat/h. Its performance was comparable with other catalysts with similar composition as shown in Table S1. The outstanding SRT performance of Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT can be attributed to the fact that Fe doping formed Ni-Fe alloy (XRD in Fig. 1B) which enhances the reducibility (H2-TPR in Fig. 3A) and sintering resistance of both Ni and Fe ( Fig. 5), increases their dispersion (Table 1), as well as facilitates the transfer of electrons from Fe to Ni (XPS in Fig. 3D and E). This leads to the generation of more Ni0 species (Table 4) and promotes the adsorption of type III water (Table 3) due to the more positive charge of the Fe surface, thereby promoting the cleavage of H-OH bonds in water and generating a significant amount of active oxygen species. DFT calculations (Fig. 7) further proved that, Fe doping promoted water adsorption, boosted the activation of both toluene and water, decreased the energy barrier for water splitting, and lowered down the heat absorption of the key methyl dehydrogenation step during toluene cracking, which shall be discussed in detail later. These factors not only facilitate the cracking of toluene but also inhibits carbon deposition, resulting in its highest activity and stability for SRT. By comparison, for Ni/CeO2/CNT, although high Ni0 ratio (XPS in Fig. 3D and Table 4) brought about high SRT activity, the largest crystalline size of Ni0 (Table 1) lead to the deposition of the greatest amount of carbon (Fig. 5A), resulting in its low stability. As for Fe/CeO2/CNT, its lowest SRT activity can be ascribed to its low Fe0 ratio and lowest dispersion as the result of its low reducibility as confirmed from the XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, and H2 chemisorption results. It lowest SRT activity i.e. toluene conversion contributed to its least carbon deposition. 3.2.4 Characterization of M/CeO2/CNT after reaction In order to confirm the relationship between the structure and SRT performance discussed above, spent catalysts after the reaction were characterized by TG-DTG, XRD, and TEM as illustrated in Fig. 5. As shown in Fig. 5A, with the increase of temperature, the mass of the three catalysts continued to decrease, which was mainly due to the combustion of CNTs and carbon deposits in the catalysts. Therefore, the influence of CNTs should be deducted when calculating the content of carbon deposits in the spent catalysts, so the content of carbon deposition was determined by Eq. S1. In summary, the carbon deposits in the three spent catalysts Ni/CeO2/CNT, Fe/CeO2/CNT, and Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT accounted for 85.8 %, 2.4 % and 3.13 % respectively. It can be seen that the carbon deposition for Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT was much less than that for Ni/CeO2/CNT. These results indicate that the doping of Fe improved the carbon resistance of Ni/CeO2/CNT probably because Fe enhanced the water adsorption (Fig. 3B) and its subsequent splitting to introduce more oxygen species to eliminate the deposited carbon species. The amount of deposited carbon on Fe/CeO2/CNT, on the other hand, was comparable to that on Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT because of its low SRT activity. The Raman spectra of the spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 5C. In accordance with literature reports, the Raman spectra were deconvoluted into four bands [59]. The D band at approximately 1340 cm−1 and the G band at approximately 1580 cm−1 correspond to amorphous carbon and graphitic carbon on the catalyst surfaces, respectively [60]. The intensity ratio of IG/ID reflects the degree of graphitization of the deposited carbon [61]. Calculations revealed that Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT exhibited a markedly lower IG/ID ratio (0.73) than the other two catalysts, indicating its lowest degree of carbon graphitization. This characteristic enhances its reactivity with active oxygen species generated from water splitting, thus explaining its lower coke accumulation after prolonged reaction. In contrast, Ni/CeO2/CNT showed a higher IG/ID ratio, signifying its inferior coke resistance. This observation is consistent with the TG analysis results. The highest XRD peak intensity of CNTs for Ni/CeO2/CNT (Fig. 5D), indicating its largest amount of carbon deposition which is consistent with the TG results (Fig. 5A). The crystalline size of Ni increased by 13.2 % compared with the fresh catalyst (Fig. 1B), accounting for its highest carbon deposition. By comparison, for Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT, although Ni-Fe alloy transformed into Ni0 and Fe3O4 (JCPDS No.19–0629) after reaction, the crystalline size of Ni0 was 14.7 nm which was much smaller than that in Ni/CeO2/CNT, demonstrating the high Ni0 sintering resistance by forming Ni-Fe alloy thereby maintaining its SRT activity. Compared with the morphology of the spent Ni/CeO2/CNT in Fig. 5E, Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT showed less sintering after reaction (Fig. 5G). Additionally, the formed Fe3O4 species can provide lattice oxygen to consume the deposited carbon species therefore improving the SRT stability of Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT [18]. Further, it was noted that Fe3O4 also has a high water adsorption ability confirmed from the H2O-TPD data of Fe/CeO2/CNT (Fig. 3B) which contains mostly Fe3O4 as discussed in the XRD results in Fig. 1B, promoting the water splitting [62,63] and maintaining the carbon resistance of Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT. However, for Fe/CeO2/CNT, the only active Fe0 species for toluene cracking were oxidized to Fe3O4 during SRT reaction [64], leading to its low SRT activity. 3.3 The mechanism of Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst in SRT 3.3.1 In-situ DRIFTS experiments In order to figure out the reaction mechanism of SRT over Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT, in-situ DRIFTS experiments were conducted to observe the intermediates generated at different reaction temperatures as shown in Fig. 6. The peaks at 3072 and 3041 cm−1 are the stretching vibrations of C-H bond on the benzene ring. The vibrational bands at 2933 and 2881 cm−1 correspond to the C-H stretching modes of methylene groups in benzyl intermediates, demonstrating the occurrence of the dehydrogenation of methyl group in toluene molecules. The stretching vibration peaks belonging to CC on the benzene ring are located at 1610 and 1498 cm−1 [33]. It can be found that with the increase of reaction temperature, the intensity of these characteristic absorption peaks related to toluene decreases, indicating that high temperature promotes the toluene conversion, which is consistent with the results in Fig. 4A. Furthermore, the attenuation of the characteristic peak at 3041 cm−1 indicates the structural alteration of the methyl group in toluene, providing additional evidence that the activation of toluene molecules initiates primarily at the methyl group [33]. In addition, the characteristic peaks of benzyl alcohol (1031 cm−1), benzaldehyde (2846 and 2737 cm−1), and benzoate (1558, 1537 and 1385 cm−1) were observed, which are considered to be the key intermediates in SRT [36,65,66]. Characteristic peaks observed at 1948, 1807, 1306 cm−1 indicate that maleic anhydride was formed in the reaction [37]. Finally, the characteristic absorption peaks of CO2 and CO are located at 2360 cm−1 and 2142 cm−1, respectively [7,10]. When the reaction temperature was higher than 600 °C, the peak intensity of CO2 was weakened due to the occurrence of RWGS reaction, which was in accordance with the previous discussion in the catalytic performance section. 3.3.2 DFT calculations In order to further confirm the effect of Fe doping on the structure and SRT performance of the Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst, Ni-Fe slab and Ni slab models were constructed for DFT calculations (Fig. S3). Firstly, the energy barriers for water splitting over different catalysts were calculated as shown in Fig. 7 A. It is clear that after the addition of Fe for Ni-Fe catalyst, the energy barrier significantly decreases, which confirms that Fe can act as a facilitator for the water splitting reaction. Since benzoate is a key intermediate as discussed in the in-situ DRIFTS experiments (Fig. 6), the potential energy diagram from toluene to benzoate was also calculated and depicted in Fig. 7B. It can be found that methyl dehydrogenation is the step that absorbs the most heat in the whole process, which can be deemed as the rate-determining step (RDS) of SRT. Additionally, Ni-Fe has less heat absorption in this step, indicating that toluene is more easily to be activated on its surface. To unveil the effect of electron transfer on the activation of toluene and H2O molecules, difference of charge density was calculated as shown in Fig. 7 C to F. From Fig. 7 C and D, it was found that more electrons were transferred from Ni-Fe surface to the benzene ring compared with that from Ni surface, resulting in the more obvious deformation of the benzene ring and thus easier toluene activation. A similar phenomenon was also observed from Fig. 7E and F. When Fe was added to the catalyst, more electrons were transferred to water molecules, which was also the fundamental reason for the improved water splitting ability of the Ni-Fe catalyst (Fig. 7 A). Further analysis of the electrostatic surface potential of Ni-Fe shows that the Fe sites have higher electrostatic potential than that of the Ni sites (Fig. S4), leading to the better interaction with the O in water molecules. Projected density of states (PDOS) of Ni and Fe elements in the two models were also calculated to compare the differences in their electronic structures as illustrated in Fig. 7 G. It can be found that the d orbital of Fe in Ni-Fe obviously has higher density of states above the Fermi level due to the existence of more empty orbitals, making it easier for Fe to coordinate with the lone-pair electrons of O in water molecules and thus promoting the splitting of water as discussed in Fig. 7 A. Further, it can also be seen that the d-band center of Fe is significantly higher than that of Ni, resulting in the stronger adsorption between Fe and reactants or reaction intermediates. Furthermore, after the formation of Ni-Fe alloy, the electrons on Fe shift to one side of Ni, filling the empty orbital on Ni, increasing the Fermi level of Ni and relatively moving down the d band center. This decreased the adsorption strength of the reaction intermediates and promoted the hydrogen evolution reaction at the Ni sites. Therefore, water will be adsorbed at the Fe sites and split into H* and OH* which will spill over to the Ni sites to generate H2 and other intermediates. Therefore, Fe and Ni in Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT form double active sites, synergistically promoting the splitting of H2O and the cracking of toluene, respectively in SRT. 3.3.3 The SRT mechanism over Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT Based on the reaction intermediates observed in the in-situ DRIFTS experiments (Fig. 6) and the DFT calculation results (Fig. 7), the reaction mechanism was proposed as shown in Fig. 8. Initially, H2O and toluene are adsorbed onto the Fe and Ni active sites, respectively due to the higher density states of d orbital, electrostatic potential, as well as the d-band center of the former (Fig. 7 G). The adsorbed H2O on the Fe site undergoes dissociation to form OH* and H* because of the lower energy barrier for water splitting (Fig. 7 A). The adsorbed toluene on the Ni site decomposes into H* and C6H5CH2* intermediates evidenced from the peaks at 2933 and 2881 cm−1 and the decrease in the peak intensity at 3041 cm−1 from the in-situ DRIFTS experiments (Fig. 6) [33]. Additionally, DFT calculation also proved this step as the RDS during toluene cracking (Fig. 7B). Subsequently, the OH* on the Fe site spillovers to react with C6H5CH2* on the Ni surface to produce benzyl alcohol (C6H5CH2OH*) confirmed from the 1031 cm−1 bands in the in-situ DRIFTS experiments (Fig. 6). Meanwhile, the H* spills over to the Ni site to combine with other H* on the Ni surface to form H2* and desorb to form H2 ascribed to the lower d-band center of Ni site (Fig. 7 G). As the reaction progresses, additional H2O adsorbs on the Fe site and continues to dissociate, replenishing the OH* and H*. Simultaneously, C6H5CH2OH* on the Ni surface undergoes dehydrogenation to form H2 and benzaldehyde (C6H5CHO*) (2846 and 2737 cm−1 bands in Fig. 6). C6H5CHO* continues to dehydrogenate to form H* and C6H5CO*(1558, 1537 and 1385 cm−1 bands in Fig. 6), which is then oxidized by OH* from the Fe site to yield benzoic acid (C6H5COOH*) (1558, 1537 and 1385 cm−1 bands in Fig. 6). Finally, C6H5COOH* undergoes deep oxidation, leading to ring-opening and conversion into maleic anhydride, which is further decomposed into CO, CO2, and CH4 through subsequent reactions. 4 Conclusions To elucidate the promoting effect of Fe on nickel-based catalysts in SRT, Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT was prepared via the impregnation and precipitation method. Under the reaction conditions of S/C= 2 and 700 °C, the Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst exhibited the highest TOF, lowest Ea, and maintained a toluene conversion above 80 % over a TOS of 50 h with the highest H2 yield. The outstanding SRT performance can be attributed to the formation of Ni-Fe alloy which promoted the reducibility of Fe species, reduced the active Ni size and increased the Ni0 ratio, improved metal dispersion, increased the sintering resistance of metal, boosted the electron transfer between Ni and Fe confirmed from the XRD, H2-TPR, H2 chemisorption, and XPS analysis. Additionally, the addition of Fe significantly improved the water adsorption capacity, particularly for type III water, and the water dissociation capabilities demonstrated from the H2O-TPD and H2O-TPSR tests (Fig. 3B-C and Table 3), providing more active oxygen for toluene conversion and carbon elimination during SRT. Finally, reaction mechanism was investigated based on the in-situ DRIFTS experiments and DFT calculations. DFT calculations revealed that the d orbital of Fe in Ni-Fe has higher density of states above the Fermi level due to the existence of more empty orbitals (Fig. 7 G), making it easier for Fe to coordinate with the lone-pair electrons of O in water molecules. Additionally, Fe sites have higher electrostatic potential and d-band center than that of the Ni sites (Fig. 7 G), leading to the stronger interaction with the O in water molecules. By contrast, Ni sites have lower d-band center thereby boosting the desorption of H2 and other intermediates during toluene dehydrogenation. Further, from the difference of charge density (Fig. 7C-F), it was found that more electrons were transferred to water and toluene molecules, making Ni-Fe catalyst easier for both water and toluene activation. Fe doping decreases the energy barrier for water splitting (Fig. 7 A) and lowers down the heat absorption for the RDS of methyl dehydrogenation (Fig. 7B). It was found that Ni and Fe in the Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT served as active sites for toluene and water, respectively. The formation of the Ni-Fe alloy altered the electronic structure of Fe, making it more favorable for water adsorption and activation. In contrast, the Ni/CeO2/CNT catalyst suffered from rapid deactivation caused by excessive carbon deposition due to its largest Ni size. The Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst exhibited the lowest activity in SRT due to its lowest reducibility and least ratio of Fe0 species for toluene cracking. Our findings on the promotional effect of Fe are valuable to develop other stable Fe based catalysts for steam reforming of tar. coredata.dc:description: Steam reforming of tar represents a cost-effective approach for tar removal in biomass gasification. Here, we developed a Ni-Fe/CeO2/CNT catalyst and unveil the effect of Fe for steam reforming of toluene (SRT) which is a representative tar model compound. The catalyst demonstrated exceptional stability (above 80 % toluene conversion, 3000 mmol/gcat/h H2 yield) over 50 h. The outstanding performance is attributed to the effect of Fe in forming Ni-Fe alloy with the highest reducibility, dispersion, Ni0 ratio, and increased sintering resistance, alongside enhanced electron transfer between Ni and Fe. Fe also promotes H2O adsorption, providing active oxygen for toluene conversion and carbon elimination. Finally, reaction mechanism was explored based on the in-situ DRIFTS and DFT calculations. DFT calculations revealed that Fe sites exhibit higher density of states, electrostatic potential, and d-band center than Ni sites, facilitating H2O coordination. Fe doping reduces energy barriers for H2O splitting and methyl dehydrogenation, while Ni promotes H2 desorption. The synergistic Ni-Fe interaction enables distinct activation of toluene and H2O, respectively. Comparative studies showed Ni/CeO2/CNT suffers from carbon deposition, while Fe/CeO2/CNT exhibits limited activity due to poor reducibility and low Fe0 content. These findings provide critical insights for designing stable Fe-based catalysts for efficient tar removal.
